title: Rates of Change - changing rates of change

content.question: ​The function <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> is defined for all real values of <math alttext="x"><mi>x</mi></math>. For a constant <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> from <math alttext="x equals a"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi></math> to <math alttext="x equals a plus 1"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math> is given by the expression <math alttext="2 a plus 1"><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: ​The average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> over consecutive equal-length input-value intervals is positive, so the graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a line with a positive slope.

​The average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> over consecutive equal-length input-value intervals is positive, so the graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a parabola that opens up.

​The average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> over consecutive equal-length input-value intervals is increasing at a constant rate, so the graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a line with a positive slope.

​The average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> over consecutive equal-length input-value intervals is increasing at a constant rate, so the graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a parabola that opens up.

content.answer: ​The average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> over consecutive equal-length input-value intervals is increasing at a constant rate, so the graph of <math alttext="f"><mi>f</mi></math> could be a parabola that opens up.
